title: The Letters of Robert Louis Stevenson - Volume 1
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Half an hour later, the inhabitants of Bush Street observe the same slender gentleman armed, like George Washington, with his little hatchet, splitting, kindling and breaking coal for his fire. He does this quasi-publicly upon the window-sill; but this is not to be attributed to any love of notoriety, though he is indeed vain of his prowess with the hatchet (which he persists in calling an axe), and daily surprised at the perpetuation of his fingers.

title: The Wrecker
author: Osbourne, Lloyd
snippet: Any scheme was welcome which allowed me to postpone the hour ofexplanation, and avoid (were it only for a breathing space) the topicof the Flying Scud. I hastened accordingly to Bush Street. Mrs. Speedy,already rejoicing in the return of a spouse, hailed me with acclamation.

title: The wrecker
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Any scheme was welcome which allowed me to postpone the hour of explanation, and avoid (were it only for a breathing space) the topic of the FLYING SCUD. I hastened accordingly to Bush Street. Mrs. Speedy, already rejoicing in the return of a spouse, hailed me with acclamation.

author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Any scheme was welcome which allowed me to postpone  the hour of explanation, and avoid (were it only for a breathing space) the topic of the Flying Scud. I hastened accordingly to Bush Street. Mrs. Speedy, already rejoicing in the return of a spouse, hailed me with acclamation.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: 608 Bush Street, San Franusco, January, 1880. MY DEAR HENLEY, —You have got a letter ahead of me, owing to the Alpine accumulation of ill news I had to stagger  under.

title: Nineteenth century letters,
author: Rees, Byron Johnson
snippet: Half an hour later, the inhabitants of Bush Street obser^^e the same slender gentleman armed, like George Washington, with his little hatchet, splitting kindling, and breaking coal for his fire. He does this quasi-publicly upon the window-sill; but this is not to be attributed to any love of notoriety, though he is indeed vain of his prowess with the hatchet (which he persists in calling an axe), and daily surprised at the perpetuation of his fingers.

title: Nineteenth century letters,
author: Rees, Byron Johnson
snippet: Half an hour later, the inhabitants of Bush Street observe the same slender gentleman armed, like George Washington, with his little hatchet, splitting kindling, and breaking coal for his fire. He does this quasi-publicly upon the window-sill; but this is not to be attributed to any love of notoriety, though he is indeed vain of his prowess with the hatchet (which he persists in calling an axe), and daily surprised at the perpetuation of his fingers.

title: Nineteenth century letters,
author: Rees, Byron Johnson
snippet: His next appearance is at the restaurant of one Dona- dieu, in Bush Street, between Dupont and Kearney, where a copious meal, half a bottle of wine, coffee and brandy may be procured for the sum of four bits, alias fifty cents, £0. 2s.

title: The Wrecker
author: Osbourne, Lloyd
snippet: I was reckless; I knew not what wasmine and cared not: I must take what I could get and give as I was able;to rob and to squander seemed the complementary parts of my new destiny. I walked up Bush Street, whistling, brazening myself to confront Mamiein the first place, and the world at large and a certain visionary judgeupon a bench in the second. Just outside, I stopped and lighted a cigarto give me greater countenance; and puffing this and wearing what (Iam sure) was a wretched assumption of braggadocio, I reappeared on thescene of my disgrace.

title: The wrecker
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: I was reckless; I knew not what was mine, and cared not: I must take what I could get and give as I was able; to rob and to squander seemed the complementary parts of my new destiny. I walked up Bush Street, whistling, brazening myself to confront Mamie in the first place, and the world at large and a certain visionary judge upon a bench in the second. Just outside, I stopped and lighted a cigar to give me greater countenance; and puffing this and wearing what (I am sure) was a wretched assumption of braggadocio, I reappeared on the scene of my disgrace.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: 608 Bush Street, San Francisco, California, Jan. 2^, 1880. MY dear and kind WEG, — It was a lesson in philosophy  that would have moved a bear, to receive your letter in my present temper.

I walked up Bush Street, whistling, brazening myself to confront Mamie in the first place, and the world at large and a certain visionary judge upon a bench in the second. Just outside, I stopped and lighted a cigar to give me greater countenance; and puffing this and wearing what (I am sure) was a wretched assumption of braggadocio, I reappeared on the scene of my disgrace.
